topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: What Can We Learn from Data?

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions to be answered based on variation in one-variable data.

essential_knowledge.summary: Numbers can convey meaningful information when placed in context.

topics.topic_title: The Language of Variation: Variables

learning_objectives.summary: Identify variables in a set of data.
Classify types of variables.

essential_knowledge.summary: A variable is a characteristic that changes from one individual to another.
A categorical variable takes on values that are category names or group labels.
A quantitative variable takes on numerical values for a measured or counted quantity.

topics.topic_title: Representing a Categorical Variable with Tables

learning_objectives.summary: Represent categorical data using frequency or relative frequency tables.
Describe categorical data represented in frequency or relative tables.

essential_knowledge.summary: A frequency table shows counts per category; a relative frequency table shows proportions.
Percentages, relative frequencies, and rates provide the same information as proportions.
Counts and relative frequencies of categorical data can be used to justify claims about the data in context.

topics.topic_title: Representing a Categorical Variable with Graphs

learning_objectives.summary: Represent categorical data graphically.
Describe categorical data represented graphically.
Compare multiple sets of categorical data.

essential_knowledge.summary: Bar charts display frequencies or relative frequencies for categorical data.
The length of a bar in a bar graph corresponds to the count or proportion of observations in a category.
Many other types of graphs can represent frequencies for categorical data.
Graphical representations of a categorical variable can justify claims about the data in context.
Frequency tables and bar graphs can be used to compare two or more data sets for the same categorical variable.

topics.topic_title: Representing a Quantitative Variable with Graphs

learning_objectives.summary: Classify types of quantitative variables.
Represent quantitative data graphically.

essential_knowledge.summary: A discrete variable can take a countable number of values.
A continuous variable can take on infinitely many values within an interval.
A histogram's bar height shows the number or proportion of observations in an interval.
A stem and leaf plot splits each data value into a 'stem' and a 'leaf'.
A dotplot represents each observation with a dot on a horizontal axis.
A cumulative graph shows the number or proportion of data less than or equal to a given value.
Many other graphical representations exist for quantitative data distributions.

topics.topic_title: Describing the Distribution of a Quantitative Variable

learning_objectives.summary: Describe the characteristics of quantitative data distributions.

essential_knowledge.summary: Descriptions of quantitative data include shape, center, variability, and unusual features like outliers, gaps, clusters, or multiple peaks.
Outliers are data points that are unusually small or large relative to the rest of the data.
A distribution's skew is determined by the length of its tails; symmetric distributions have mirrored halves.
Distributions can be described by their number of peaks (unimodal, bimodal) or as approximately uniform.
A gap is a region in a distribution with no observed data.
Clusters are concentrations of data, usually separated by gaps.
Descriptive statistics summarize a data set but do not attribute its properties to a larger population.

topics.topic_title: Summary Statistics for a Quantitative Variable

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate measures of center and position for quantitative data.
Calculate measures of variability for quantitative data.
Explain the selection of a particular measure of center and/or variability for describing a set of quantitative data.

essential_knowledge.summary: A statistic is a numerical summary of sample data.
The mean is the sum of data values divided by the number of values.
The median is the middle value of an ordered data set.
The first quartile (Q1) and third quartile (Q3) are the medians of the lower and upper halves of the data, respectively.
The Pth percentile is the value that has p% of the data less than or equal to it.
Common measures of variability are range, interquartile range (IQR), and standard deviation.
Range is the difference between the maximum and minimum values; IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.
Standard deviation measures variability; its square is called the variance.
Changing units of measurement affects calculated statistics.
Outliers can be identified as values more than 1.5xIQR beyond the quartiles or 2 or more standard deviations from the mean.
Mean, standard deviation, and range are nonresistant to outliers, while median and IQR are resistant.

topics.topic_title: Graphical Representations of Summary Statistics

learning_objectives.summary: Represent summary statistics for quantitative data graphically.
Describe summary statistics of quantitative data represented graphically.

essential_knowledge.summary: The five-number summary consists of the minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum.
A boxplot is a graphical representation of the five-number summary.
Summary statistics can be used to justify claims about quantitative data in context.
The relationship between mean and median is affected by the skewness of the distribution.

topics.topic_title: Comparing Distributions of a Quantitative Variable

learning_objectives.summary: Compare graphical representations for multiple sets of quantitative data.
Compare summary statistics for multiple sets of quantitative data.

essential_knowledge.summary: Graphical representations can be used to compare two or more independent samples on various features.
Numerical summaries can be used to compare two or more independent samples.

topics.topic_title: The Normal Distribution

learning_objectives.summary: Compare a data distribution to the normal distribution model.
Determine proportions and percentiles from a normal distribution.
Compare measures of relative position in data sets.

essential_knowledge.summary: A parameter is a numerical summary of a population.
A normal distribution is mound-shaped and symmetric, defined by its population mean and standard deviation.
The empirical rule states that for a normal distribution, approximately 68%, 95%, and 99.7% of observations fall within 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations of the mean, respectively.
Many variables can be modeled by a normal distribution.
A standardized score measures how many standard deviations a data value is from the mean.
A z-score is a standardized score calculated as (value - mean) / standard deviation.
Technology or tables can find the proportion of data values on a given interval of a normal distribution.
Given an area under the normal curve, technology or tables can be used to estimate population parameters.
Percentiles and z-scores can be used to compare the relative positions of points within or between data sets.

topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Are Variables Related?

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions to be answered about possible relationships in data.

essential_knowledge.summary: Apparent patterns and associations in data may be random or not.

topics.topic_title: Representing Two Categorical Variables

learning_objectives.summary: Compare numerical and graphical representations for two categorical variables.

essential_knowledge.summary: Side-by-side, segmented, and mosaic bar graphs are used for two categorical variables.
Graphical representations of two categorical variables can compare distributions or determine association.
A two-way table (contingency table) summarizes two categorical variables with frequencies or relative frequencies.
A joint relative frequency is a cell frequency divided by the total for the entire table.

topics.topic_title: Statistics for Two Categorical Variables

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate statistics for two categorical variables.
Compare statistics for two categorical variables.

essential_knowledge.summary: Marginal relative frequencies are row or column totals divided by the grand total in a two-way table.
A conditional relative frequency is a relative frequency for a specific part of a contingency table.
Summary statistics for two categorical variables can compare distributions or determine association.

topics.topic_title: Representing the Relationship Between Two Quantitative Variables

learning_objectives.summary: Represent bivariate quantitative data using scatterplots.
Describe the characteristics of a scatter plot.

essential_knowledge.summary: A bivariate quantitative data set consists of observations of two different quantitative variables.
A scatterplot shows two numeric values for each observation, one for the x-axis and one for the y-axis.
An explanatory variable is used to explain or predict values of the response variable.
A description of a scatter plot includes form, direction, strength, and unusual features.
The direction of association in a scatterplot can be positive or negative.
A positive association means as one variable increases, the other tends to increase; a negative association means as one increases, the other tends to decrease.
The form of association can be described as linear or non-linear.
The strength of association is how closely points follow a pattern and can be described as strong, moderate, or weak.
Unusual features of a scatter plot include clusters or points with large residuals.

topics.topic_title: Correlation

learning_objectives.summary: Determine the correlation for a linear relationship.
Interpret the correlation for a linear relationship.

essential_knowledge.summary: The correlation, r, gives the direction and quantifies the strength of a linear association.
The correlation coefficient is most commonly determined using technology.
A correlation coefficient close to 1 or -1 does not necessarily mean a linear model is appropriate.
Correlation, r, is unit-free and always between -1 and 1. A value of 0 indicates no linear association.
Correlation does not necessarily imply causation.

topics.topic_title: Linear Regression Models

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate a predicted response value using a linear regression model.

essential_knowledge.summary: A simple linear regression model is an equation that uses an explanatory variable, x, to predict a response variable, y.
The predicted response value is calculated as y-hat = a + bx, where a is the y-intercept and b is the slope.
Extrapolation is predicting a response for an x-value outside the interval used to determine the regression line; it is less reliable.

topics.topic_title: Residuals

learning_objectives.summary: Represent differences between measured and predicted responses using residual plots.
Describe the form of association of bivariate data using residual plots.

essential_knowledge.summary: A residual is the difference between the actual and predicted value: residual = y - y-hat.
A residual plot is a plot of residuals versus explanatory variable values or predicted response values.
Apparent randomness in a residual plot for a linear model suggests a linear form of association.
Residual plots can be used to investigate the appropriateness of a selected model.

topics.topic_title: Least Squares Regression

learning_objectives.summary: Estimate parameters for the least-squares regression line model.
Interpret coefficients for the least-squares regression line model.

essential_knowledge.summary: The least-squares regression model minimizes the sum of squared residuals and passes through the point (x-bar, y-bar).
The slope, b, of the regression line can be calculated as b = r(sy/sx).
The y-intercept may not have a logical interpretation in context.
r-squared, the coefficient of determination, is the proportion of variation in the response variable explained by the model.
The coefficients of the least-squares regression model are the estimated slope and y-intercept.
The slope is the amount the predicted y-value changes for every unit increase in x.
The y-intercept is the predicted y-value when the explanatory variable is 0.

topics.topic_title: Analyzing Departures from Linearity

learning_objectives.summary: Identify influential points in regression.
Calculate a predicted response using a least-squares regression line for a transformed data set.

essential_knowledge.summary: An outlier in regression does not follow the general trend and has a large residual.
A high-leverage point has a substantially larger or smaller x-value than other observations.
An influential point, if removed, substantially changes the regression model.
Transforming variables can create a data set that is more linear.
Increased randomness in residual plots and an r-squared value closer to 1 after transformation suggest a more appropriate model.

topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Do the Data We Collected Tell the Truth?

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions to be answered about data collection methods.

essential_knowledge.summary: Data collection methods not based on chance can lead to untrustworthy conclusions.

topics.topic_title: Introduction to Planning a Study

learning_objectives.summary: Identify the type of a study.
Identify appropriate generalizations and determinations based on observational studies.

essential_knowledge.summary: A population consists of all items or subjects of interest.
A sample is a subset of the population.
In an observational study, treatments are not imposed; investigators simply observe.
In an experiment, different conditions (treatments) are assigned to experimental units.
Generalizations about a population can only be made from randomly selected or representative samples.
A sample is only generalizable to the population from which it was selected.
Causal relationships cannot be determined from an observational study.

topics.topic_title: Random Sampling and Data Collection

learning_objectives.summary: Identify a sampling method, given a description of a study.
Explain why a particular sampling method is or is not appropriate for a given situation.

essential_knowledge.summary: Sampling without replacement means an item can be selected only once; with replacement, it can be selected multiple times.
A simple random sample (SRS) is one where every group of a given size has an equal chance of being chosen.
A stratified random sample divides a population into strata (homogeneous groups) and takes an SRS from each.
A cluster sample divides a population into clusters, randomly selects some clusters, and collects data from all individuals in those clusters.
A systematic random sample selects members from a population at a fixed periodic interval from a random starting point.
A census selects all items/subjects in a population.
Each sampling method has advantages and disadvantages depending on the situation.

topics.topic_title: Potential Problems with Sampling

learning_objectives.summary: Identify potential sources of bias in sampling methods.

essential_knowledge.summary: Bias occurs when certain responses are systematically favored over others.
Voluntary response bias occurs when a sample is comprised entirely of volunteers.
Undercoverage bias occurs when part of the population has a reduced chance of being included in the sample.
Nonresponse bias occurs when individuals chosen for the sample cannot be reached or refuse to respond.
Response bias results from problems in the data gathering process, like leading questions.
Non-random sampling methods introduce potential for bias because they do not use chance.

topics.topic_title: Introduction to Experimental Design

learning_objectives.summary: Identify the components of an experiment.
Describe elements of a well-designed experiment.
Compare experimental designs and methods.

essential_knowledge.summary: Experimental units are the individuals to which treatments are assigned.
An explanatory variable (factor) is intentionally manipulated; its levels are called treatments.
A response variable is the outcome measured after treatments have been administered.
A confounding variable is related to the explanatory variable and influences the response variable.
A well-designed experiment includes comparison of treatments, random assignment, replication, and control of confounding variables.
In a completely randomized design, treatments are assigned to experimental units completely at random.
Methods for random assignment include random number generators, tables, or drawing chips.
In a single-blind experiment, either the subjects or the researchers do not know which treatment is being received.
In a double-blind experiment, neither the subjects nor the interacting researchers know which treatment is being received.
A control group receives no treatment or a placebo to determine if the treatment of interest has an effect.
The placebo effect occurs when experimental units have a response to a placebo.
In a randomized complete block design, treatments are assigned randomly within each block.
Blocking ensures units within each block are similar, helping to separate natural variability from treatment effects.
A matched pairs design is a special case of a block design where subjects are arranged in pairs.

topics.topic_title: Selecting an Experimental Design

learning_objectives.summary: Explain why a particular experimental design is appropriate.

essential_knowledge.summary: Each experimental design has advantages and disadvantages depending on the research question and resources.

topics.topic_title: Inference and Experiments

learning_objectives.summary: Interpret the results of a well-designed experiment.

essential_knowledge.summary: Statistical inference attributes conclusions based on data to the distribution from which it was collected.
Random assignment allows concluding that observed changes are unlikely to be due to chance, i.e., are statistically significant.
Statistically significant differences between treatment groups are evidence that the treatments caused the effect.
If experimental units are representative of a larger group, results can be generalized to that group.

units.unit_title: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Random and Non-Random Patterns?

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions suggested by patterns in data.

essential_knowledge.summary: Patterns in data do not necessarily mean that variation is not random.

topics.topic_title: Estimating Probabilities Using Simulation

learning_objectives.summary: Estimate probabilities using simulation.

essential_knowledge.summary: A random process generates results determined by chance.
An outcome is the result of a trial of a random process.
An event is a collection of outcomes.
Simulation is a way to model random events.
The relative frequency of an event in a simulation can be used to estimate its probability.
The law of large numbers states that empirical probabilities approach true probabilities as the number of trials increases.

topics.topic_title: Introduction to Probability

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate probabilities for events and their complements.
Interpret probabilities for events.

essential_knowledge.summary: The sample space is the set of all possible non-overlapping outcomes.
If all outcomes are equally likely, P(E) = (number of outcomes in E) / (total number of outcomes).
The probability of an event is a number between 0 and 1, inclusive.
The probability of the complement of an event E is 1 - P(E).
Probability can be interpreted as the long-run relative frequency of an event.

topics.topic_title: Mutually Exclusive Events

learning_objectives.summary: Explain why two events are (or are not) mutually exclusive.

essential_knowledge.summary: The joint probability, P(A and B), is the probability of the intersection of events A and B.
Two events are mutually exclusive (disjoint) if they cannot occur at the same time, so P(A and B) = 0.

topics.topic_title: Conditional Probability

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate conditional probabilities.

essential_knowledge.summary: The conditional probability P(A|B) is P(A and B) / P(B).
The multiplication rule states P(A and B) = P(A) * P(B|A).

topics.topic_title: Independent Events and Unions of Events

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate probabilities for independent events and for the union of two events.

essential_knowledge.summary: Events A and B are independent if knowing A occurs does not change the probability of B.
If events A and B are independent, P(A|B) = P(A), P(B|A) = P(B), and P(A and B) = P(A) * P(B).
The probability of the union of A and B, P(A or B), is the probability that A, B, or both occur.
The addition rule states P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B).

topics.topic_title: Introduction to Random Variables and Probability Distributions

learning_objectives.summary: Represent the probability distribution for a discrete random variable.
Interpret a probability distribution.

essential_knowledge.summary: The values of a random variable are the numerical outcomes of random behavior.
A discrete random variable can take a countable number of values, with the sum of probabilities equal to 1.
A probability distribution can be represented by a graph, table, or function.
A cumulative probability distribution shows the probability of being less than or equal to each value.
Interpreting a probability distribution provides information about the shape, center, and spread of a population.

topics.topic_title: Mean and Standard Deviation of Random Variables

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate parameters for a discrete random variable.
Interpret parameters for a discrete random variable.

essential_knowledge.summary: A parameter is a numerical value measuring a characteristic of a population or distribution.
The mean (expected value) of a discrete random variable X is the sum of (value * probability).
The standard deviation of a discrete random variable X is the square root of the sum of (squared deviation from the mean * probability).
Parameters for a discrete random variable should be interpreted in context with appropriate units.

topics.topic_title: Combining Random Variables

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate parameters for linear combinations of random variables.
Describe the effects of linear transformations of parameters of random variables.

essential_knowledge.summary: The mean of a linear combination of random variables, aX + bY, is a*mean(X) + b*mean(Y).
Two random variables are independent if knowing one does not change the probability distribution of the other.
For independent random variables, the variance of aX + bY is a^2*var(X) + b^2*var(Y).
For Y = a + bX, the shape of the probability distribution is the same. The mean is a + b*mean(X) and the standard deviation is |b|*sd(X).

topics.topic_title: Introduction to the Binomial Distribution

learning_objectives.summary: Estimate probabilities of binomial random variables using data from a simulation.
Calculate probabilities for a binomial distribution.

essential_knowledge.summary: A probability distribution can be constructed using probability rules or estimated via simulation.
A binomial random variable counts the number of successes in n independent trials with two outcomes and a constant probability of success.
The binomial probability function calculates the probability of exactly x successes in n independent trials.

topics.topic_title: Parameters for a Binomial Distribution

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate parameters for a binomial distribution.
Interpret probabilities and parameters for a binomial distribution.

essential_knowledge.summary: The mean of a binomial random variable is np, and its standard deviation is sqrt(np(1-p)).
Probabilities and parameters for a binomial distribution should be interpreted in context.

topics.topic_title: The Geometric Distribution

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate probabilities for geometric random variables.
Calculate parameters of a geometric distribution.
Interpret probabilities and parameters for a geometric distribution.

essential_knowledge.summary: A geometric random variable gives the trial number on which the first success occurs in a sequence of independent trials.
The geometric probability function calculates the probability that the first success occurs on trial x.
The mean of a geometric random variable is 1/p, and its standard deviation is sqrt(1-p)/p.
Probabilities and parameters for a geometric distribution should be interpreted in context.

topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Why Is My Sample Not Like Yours?

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions suggested by variation in statistics for samples from the same population.

essential_knowledge.summary: Variation in statistics for samples from the same population may be random or not.

topics.topic_title: The Normal Distribution, Revisited

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate the probability that a particular value lies in a given interval of a normal distribution.
Determine the interval associated with a given area in a normal distribution.
Determine the appropriateness of using the normal distribution to approximate probabilities for unknown distributions.

essential_knowledge.summary: A continuous random variable can take any value within a specified domain.
A continuous random variable with a normal distribution is described by a bell-shaped curve.
The area under a normal curve over an interval represents the probability that a value lies in that interval.
Interval boundaries for a given area in a normal distribution can be found using z-scores or technology.
Intervals associated with a given area in a normal distribution can be determined using appropriate inequalities.
Normal distributions can be used to approximate other distributions with similar symmetrical, bell-shaped characteristics.

topics.topic_title: The Central Limit Theorem

learning_objectives.summary: Estimate sampling distributions using simulation.

essential_knowledge.summary: A sampling distribution of a statistic is the distribution of values for that statistic from all possible samples of a given size.
The central limit theorem (CLT) states that for a large enough sample size, the sampling distribution of the mean will be approximately normal.
The CLT requires independent sample values and a sufficiently large sample size (n).
A randomization distribution is a collection of statistics generated by simulation assuming known parameter values.
The sampling distribution of a statistic can be simulated by generating repeated random samples from a population.

topics.topic_title: Biased and Unbiased Point Estimates

learning_objectives.summary: Explain why an estimator is or is not unbiased.
Calculate estimates for a population parameter.

essential_knowledge.summary: An estimator is unbiased if its average value equals the population parameter.
An estimator exhibits variability that can be modeled using probability.
A sample statistic serves as a point estimator for the corresponding population parameter.

topics.topic_title: Sampling Distributions for Sample Proportions

learning_objectives.summary: Determine parameters of a sampling distribution for sample proportions.
Determine whether a sampling distribution for a sample proportion can be described as approximately normal.
Interpret probabilities and parameters for a sampling distribution for a sample proportion.

essential_knowledge.summary: The sampling distribution of a sample proportion p-hat has a mean equal to p and a standard deviation of sqrt(p(1-p)/n).
If sampling without replacement and the sample size is less than 10% of the population, the standard deviation formula is approximately correct.
The sampling distribution of p-hat is approximately normal if np >= 10 and n(1-p) >= 10 (Large Counts Condition).
Probabilities and parameters for the sampling distribution of a sample proportion should be interpreted in context.

topics.topic_title: Sampling Distributions for Differences in Sample Proportions

learning_objectives.summary: Determine parameters of a sampling distribution for a difference in sample proportions.
Determine whether a sampling distribution for a difference of sample proportions can be described as approximately normal.
Interpret probabilities and parameters for a sampling distribution for a difference in proportions.

essential_knowledge.summary: The sampling distribution of the difference in sample proportions has a mean of p1 - p2 and a specific standard deviation formula.
If sampling without replacement and sample sizes are less than 10% of their populations, the standard deviation formula is approximately correct.
The sampling distribution of the difference in sample proportions is approximately normal if the Large Counts Condition is met for both samples.
Parameters for a sampling distribution for a difference of proportions should be interpreted in context.

topics.topic_title: Sampling Distributions for Sample Means

learning_objectives.summary: Determine parameters for a sampling distribution for sample means.
Determine whether a sampling distribution of a sample mean can be described as approximately normal.
Interpret probabilities and parameters for a sampling distribution for a sample mean.

essential_knowledge.summary: The sampling distribution of the sample mean x-bar has a mean equal to mu and a standard deviation of sigma/sqrt(n).
If sampling without replacement and the sample size is less than 10% of the population, the standard deviation formula is approximately correct.
If the population distribution is normal, the sampling distribution of the sample mean is also normal.
If the population distribution is not normal, the sampling distribution of the sample mean is approximately normal if the sample size is large enough (e.g., n >= 30).
Probabilities and parameters for a sampling distribution for a sample mean should be interpreted in context.

topics.topic_title: Sampling Distributions for Differences in Sample Means

learning_objectives.summary: Determine parameters of a sampling distribution for a difference in sample means.
Determine whether a sampling distribution of a difference in sample means can be described as approximately normal.
Interpret probabilities and parameters for a sampling distribution for a difference in sample means.

essential_knowledge.summary: The sampling distribution of the difference in sample means has a mean of mu1 - mu2 and a specific standard deviation formula.
If sampling without replacement and sample sizes are less than 10% of their populations, the standard deviation formula is approximately correct.
The sampling distribution of the difference in means is normal if both population distributions are normal.
If population distributions are not normal, the sampling distribution of the difference in means is approximately normal if both sample sizes are large enough (e.g., >= 30).
Probabilities and parameters for a sampling distribution for a difference of sample means should be interpreted in context.

topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Why Be Normal?

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions suggested by variation in the shapes of distributions of samples from the same population.

essential_knowledge.summary: Variation in the shapes of data distributions may be random or not.

topics.topic_title: Constructing a Confidence Interval for a Population Proportion

learning_objectives.summary: Identify an appropriate confidence interval procedure for a population proportion.
Verify the conditions for calculating confidence intervals for a population proportion.
Determine the margin of error for a given sample size and an estimate for the sample size for a given margin of error.
Calculate an appropriate confidence interval for a population proportion.
Calculate an interval estimate based on a confidence interval for a population proportion.

essential_knowledge.summary: The appropriate procedure for a one-sample proportion is a one-sample z-interval for a proportion.
To calculate a confidence interval for a population proportion, check for independence and approximate normality of the sampling distribution.
The standard error of a statistic is an estimate of its standard deviation.
A margin of error indicates how much a sample statistic is likely to vary from the population parameter.
For categorical variables, the margin of error is critical value (z*) times the standard error (SE).
The margin of error formula can be solved for n to find the minimum sample size for a given margin of error.
An interval estimate is constructed as point estimate ± margin of error.
Critical values (z*) are the boundaries for the middle C% of the standard normal distribution.
Confidence intervals for population proportions can be used to calculate interval estimates with specified units.

topics.topic_title: Justifying a Claim Based on a Confidence Interval for a Population Proportion

learning_objectives.summary: Interpret a confidence interval for a population proportion.
Justify a claim based on a confidence interval for a population proportion.
Identify relationships between sample size, confidence interval width, confidence level, and margin of error.

essential_knowledge.summary: A confidence interval either contains the population proportion or it does not.
We are C% confident that the confidence interval captures the population proportion.
In repeated sampling, approximately C% of confidence intervals created will capture the population proportion.
Interpreting a confidence interval should include reference to the sample and the population it represents.
A confidence interval provides an interval of plausible values that may support a claim.
The width of a confidence interval tends to decrease as sample size increases.
For a given sample, the width of the confidence interval increases as the confidence level increases.
The width of a confidence interval is exactly twice the margin of error.

topics.topic_title: Setting Up a Test for a Population Proportion

learning_objectives.summary: Identify the null and alternative hypotheses for a population proportion.
Identify an appropriate testing method for a population proportion.
Verify the conditions for making statistical inferences when testing a population proportion.

essential_knowledge.summary: The null hypothesis is assumed to be correct unless evidence suggests otherwise; the alternative is what is being tested for.
The null hypothesis contains an equality (=, >=, <=), while the alternative contains a strict inequality (<, >, !=).
The null hypothesis for a population proportion is H0: p = p0.
Alternative hypotheses for a proportion can be one-sided (p < p0 or p > p0) or two-sided (p != p0).
For a one-sample z-test for a proportion, the null hypothesis specifies a value for the population proportion.
The appropriate test for a single categorical variable's population proportion is a one-sample z-test.
To test a population proportion, check for independence and that the sampling distribution is approximately normal, assuming H0 is true.

topics.topic_title: Interpreting p-Values

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate an appropriate test statistic and p-value for a population proportion.
Interpret the p-value of a significance test for a population proportion.

essential_knowledge.summary: The null distribution of the test statistic is a randomization or theoretical (e.g., z) distribution.
The standardized test statistic is (sample statistic - null value) / standard deviation of the statistic.
The test statistic for a population proportion is a specific z-statistic formula.
A p-value is the probability of obtaining a test statistic as or more extreme than the observed one, assuming the null hypothesis is true.
The p-value is the proportion of the null distribution that is as or more extreme than the observed test statistic.
Interpreting a p-value for a one-sample proportion test assumes the null hypothesis is true.

topics.topic_title: Concluding a Test for a Population Proportion

learning_objectives.summary: Justify a claim about the population based on the results of a significance test for a population proportion.

essential_knowledge.summary: The significance level, alpha, is the predetermined probability of a Type I error.
A formal decision compares the p-value to alpha: if p-value <= alpha, reject H0; if p-value > alpha, fail to reject H0.
Rejecting H0 means there is sufficient evidence for Ha; failing to reject H0 means there is insufficient evidence for Ha.
The conclusion about the alternative hypothesis must be stated in context.
A significance test can never prove the null hypothesis is true.
Small p-values provide evidence for the alternative hypothesis.
Large p-values do not provide convincing evidence for the alternative, nor do they prove the null is true.
The results of a significance test provide statistical reasoning to support an answer to a research question.

topics.topic_title: Potential Errors When Performing Tests

learning_objectives.summary: Identify Type I and Type II errors.
Calculate the probability of a Type I and Type II errors.
Identify factors that affect the probability of errors in significance testing.
Interpret Type I and Type II errors.

essential_knowledge.summary: A Type I error occurs when a true null hypothesis is rejected (false positive).
A Type II error occurs when a false null hypothesis is not rejected (false negative).
The significance level, alpha, is the probability of making a Type I error if the null hypothesis is true.
The power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis.
The probability of a Type II error is 1 - power.
The probability of a Type II error decreases as sample size, significance level, or effect size increases, or as standard error decreases.
